awd_titl_txt: External Field Control of Ultracold Atom-Molecule Mixtures: Magnetic Feshbach Resonances and Sympathetic Cooling of Polyatomic Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum control of ultracold atoms, molecules, and ions with external electromagnetic fields is central to a wide variety of research fields. One widely-used control tool utilizes the sensitivity of long-lived quasi-stable (resonant) states between atoms. In particular, magnetic fields can be used to control so-called Feshbach resonances (MFRs) between atoms, a property that has been instrumental to the experimental realization of strongly correlated many-body states of matter for novel quantum materials. The prospect of controlling interactions of ultracold molecules is even more exciting, since these interactions are predicted to give rise to the highly exotic states of matter responsible for high-temperature superconductivity and novel topological phases. However, the tools for controlling molecular interactions with external magnetic fields are much less developed than those for atomic interactions, severely limiting the possibilities for controlling molecular many-body phenomena. The PI proposes to expand these possibilities by exploring MFRs in atom-molecule collisions using rigorous first-principle calculations. The study will pave the way toward precise quantum control of intermolecular interactions with applications to quantum simulation of condensed-matter systems, and to deep sympathetic cooling of trapped molecular gases.

At present, numerically exact coupled-channel (CC) methodology cannot be used to study magnetic Feshbach resonances in ultracold atom-molecule collisions. This is due to the extreme computational difficulties caused by enormous CC basis sets, which must include all low-energy vibrational, rotational, and hyperfine molecular states coupled by strongly anisotropic intermolecular interactions. Particularly challenging to describe are the numerous hyperfine states, which arise due to the coupling between the electron and nuclear spins in the molecule,  and play an important role in ultracold collisions. The PI proposes to address this issue by using flexible CC basis sets, which feature a variable number of hyperfine basis functions for different molecular rotational states.  The use of the flexible basis states could reduce the computational complexity of CC calculations by several orders of magnitude, making it computationally feasible to calculate the spectrum of magnetic Feshbach resonances in ultracold atom-molecule mixtures of current experimental interest (such as Rb-SrF).

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop a predictive quantum theory of magnetic Feshbach resonances (FRs) in ultracold atom-molecule collisions in the presence of external electromagnetic fields. Ultracold molecular collisions are important because they determine the stability and properties of ultracold molecular gases, which have recently emerged as a promising platform for quantum science and technology. Ultracold molecules are also used for precision searches of new physics beyond the Standard Model, and for detailed experimental studies of complex chemical reactions  that occur in combustion, interstellar environments, and in the Earth's atmosphere. 

The key research outcomes of this project can be summarized as follows: 

(1) Ultracold chemical reactions of alkali-metal atoms with open-shell radicals can be efficiently controlled by external dc magnetic fields and by switching the hyperfine states of the reactants [1,2]. The occurrence of magnetic FRs in ultracold chemical reactions was demonstrated by our group for the first time [2] for the  Na+NaLi -> Na2 + Li reaction observed experimentally at MIT.

(2)  It is possible to carry out numerically converged multi-surface quantum scattering calculations of spin-exchange in ultracold atom-molecule (Rb-SrF) collisions in the presence of an external magnetic field. Such calculations require  as many as 165 rotational basis states in the scattering basis. This development represents a key step towards the fully rigorous calculation of Feshbach resonances in Rb - SrF collisions including the hyperfine structure of Rb and SrF.

(3) Numerically exact exact three-dimensional quantum scattering calculations on strongly anisotropic ultracold atom-molecule (Li + CaH) collisions can be performed in the presence of an external magnetic field. These are enabled by the parity-adapted total angular momentum representation and a new three-dimensional potential energy surface for the triplet Li-CaH collision complex [3].

(4) Near-resonant angular momentum exchange processes exhibit an unconventional scaling at low collision energy, which is similar to that of elastic processes. Accurate quantum scattering calculations on resonant spin exchange in ultracold Rb + Rb and O2 + O2 collisions illustrate the modified threshold laws  and show that the threshold scaling of collision cross sections is determined only by the energetics of the underlying process (resonant vs. exothermic) rather than by whether the internal states of colliding particles is changed in the collision [4].  

(5) Unphysical states can be eliminated from quantum calculations on ultracold atom-molecule collisions in a magnetic field using an augmented total angular momentum representation [5]. 

(6) The dynamical regimes of the incoherently driven Lambda-system can be classified as underdamped and overdamped. Long-lived quantum coherent dynamics can occur  in the ground-state subspace of atomic and molecular Lambda-systems in the absence of coherent driving [6].

(7) A two-qubit system coupled to two independent baths is equivalent to  a three-level V-system driven simultaneously by both baths. The real part of the noise-induced  Fano coherence in the V-system is proportional to the deviation of excited-state populations from their values in thermodynamic equilibrium, making it possible to observe signatures of steady-state Fano coherences in excited-state populations [7].

(8) By tuning the preparation coefficients of the initial atomic spin states, we can benefit from the quantum interference between molecular channels to maximize or minimize the cross sections for Penning and associative ionization in cold  collisions of metastable He atoms [8].

 

The award supported the professional development of two graduate students, and resulted in 8 published papers [1-8], 5 invited conference presentations, and several contributed presentations  at DAMOP in 2020 and 2021. 

 

[1] T. V. Tscherbul and J. Kłos, Magnetic tuning of ultracold barrierless chemical reactions, Phys. Rev. Research 2, 013117 (2020).

[2] R. Hermsmeier, J. Kłos, S. Kotochigova, and T. V. Tscherbul, Quantum spin state selectivity and magnetic tuning of ultracold chemical reactions of triplet alkali-metal dimers with alkali-metal atoms, Phys. Rev. Lett. 127, 103402 (2021).

[3] M. Morita, J. Kłos, and T. V. Tscherbul, Full-dimensional quantum scattering calculations on ultracold atom-molecule collisions in magnetic fields: The role of molecular vibrations, Phys. Rev. Research 2, 043294 (2020).

 [4] R. Hermsmeier, A. Devolder, P. Brumer, and T. V. Tscherbul, Near-threshold scaling of resonant inelastic collisions at ultralow temperatures, Phys. Rev. A 105, L011302 (2022).

 [5] S. Koyu, R. Hermsmeier, and T. V. Tscherbul, Total angular momentum representation for state-to-state quantum scattering of cold molecules in a magnetic field, J. Chem. Phys. 156, 034112 (2022).

 [6] S. Koyu and T. V. Tscherbul, Long-lived quantum coherent dynamics of a Lambda system driven by a thermal environment, J. Chem. Phys. 157, 124302 (2022).

 [7] S. Koyu, A. Dodin, P. Brumer, and T. V. Tscherbul, Steady-state Fano coherences in a V-type system driven by polarized incoherent light, Phys. Rev. Research 3, 013295 (2021).

 [8] J. J. Omiste, T. V. Tscherbul, and P. Brumer, Coherent control mechanisms of Penning and associative ionization in cold He (3S)-He(3S) reactive scattering, Phys. Rev. A 103, 052809 (2021).
